definitions: keep away from or stop oneself from encountering or being affected by something unpleasant dangerous or unwanted
take action to prevent something undesirable from happening or to stop oneself from doing something
examples: She carefully avoided the puddles while walking home from school
The driver avoided hitting the deer by swerving quickly to the right
He avoided making any controversial statements during the interview
The company avoided bankruptcy by restructuring their debt payments successfully

definitions: wait for someone or something to arrive or happen with expectation or anticipation
be ready or waiting for someone in the future as a consequence or result
examples: The fans eagerly awaited the arrival of their favorite celebrity at the airport
She awaited the test results with nervous anticipation for several days
A difficult challenge awaits anyone who attempts to climb that mountain
Great opportunities await those who work hard and stay focused

definitions: stop sleeping and become conscious or alert especially after a period of rest
become aware conscious or alert to something important that was previously unnoticed
examples: She awoke early this morning feeling refreshed after a good night's sleep
The loud thunderstorm awoke everyone in the neighborhood around midnight
The scandal finally awoke the public to the corruption in government
His speech awoke our interest in environmental conservation issues completely

definitions: cause someone to wake up from sleep or cause oneself to become conscious
arouse or stimulate a feeling interest or awareness in someone
examples: The alarm clock awakened him at six in the morning as usual
She was awakened by the sound of birds singing outside
The documentary awakened her interest in marine biology and ocean conservation
His travels awakened a love for different cultures and traditions

definitions: give or present something officially to someone as recognition of merit achievement or victory
grant or assign something officially especially after legal proceedings or formal consideration
examples: The university awarded him an honorary doctorate for his contributions to science
She was awarded first prize in the international photography competition
The court awarded damages to the plaintiff after hearing all evidence
The arbitrator awarded the contract to the lowest bidding company

definitions: inspire someone with wonder reverence or fear through something impressive grand or powerful
examples: The magnificent cathedral awed visitors with its soaring architecture and stained glass
The sheer power of the thunderstorm awed everyone watching from safety

definitions: cut chop or split something using an axe or similar sharp tool
eliminate or remove something completely especially jobs programs or funding
examples: The lumberjack expertly axed the fallen tree into manageable pieces for transport
They axed firewood all afternoon preparing for the cold winter months ahead
The company axed three hundred jobs due to budget constraints this quarter
The government axed funding for several environmental protection programs unfortunately

definitions: make the characteristic crying sound of a sheep or similar animal
examples: The sheep baaed loudly when they saw the farmer approaching with food
The lamb baaed pitifully when separated from its mother in the field

definitions: treat someone with excessive care gentleness or protectiveness as if they were helpless
indulge or pamper someone excessively by catering to their every want or need
examples: She babies her youngest child and never lets him do anything independently
The coach refuses to baby the players and expects them to work hard
His parents baby him even though he's already thirty years old now
Don't baby me just because I have a minor injury today

definitions: fail to achieve the intended result and instead produce the opposite or harmful effect
explode prematurely or in the wrong direction especially in an engine or firearm
examples: His plan to impress her backfired when she found out he was lying
The political campaign strategy backfired and actually lost them many votes
The old car backfired loudly as it struggled up the steep hill
The rifle backfired dangerously when the ammunition was defective

definitions: place something in the background or make it less prominent than other elements
provide background information context or supporting details for better understanding
examples: The designer backgrounded the text to make the images more prominent
The photographer backgrounded the landscape to focus on the portrait subject
The reporter backgrounded the recent events before discussing the main story
Please background me on the project before the meeting starts tomorrow

definitions: hit a ball or make a strike using the back of the hand or backhand technique
give someone a compliment that contains an insult or criticism within it
examples: She backhanded the tennis ball perfectly down the line for a winner
He backhanded the hockey puck into the net with incredible accuracy
She backhanded him with praise about his improved appearance implying he looked bad before
His comment backhanded her achievements by suggesting they were due to luck

definitions: react with strong negative response or opposition against something especially a previous action or policy
examples: The public backlashed against the new tax policy with protests and petitions
Employees backlashed when management announced the pay cuts without warning

definitions: travel especially hiking or camping while carrying supplies in a backpack
carry something in a backpack or attach it to a backpack for transport
examples: They backpacked through Europe for three months visiting twelve different countries
She loves to backpack in the mountains during her summer vacations
He backpacked all his camera equipment to the remote location for photography
Students backpack their textbooks and laptops to classes every day

definitions: provide support or assistance as a backup or safety measure in case something fails
act as a barrier or obstacle to prevent something from going too far
examples: The experienced manager backstopped the new employee during her first difficult project
Federal insurance backstops bank deposits to protect consumers from losses
The fence backstopped the baseball field to prevent balls from leaving the area
Additional funding backstopped the program when initial resources proved insufficient

definitions: swim using the backstroke technique lying on the back and alternating arm movements
examples: She backstroked fifty meters in the swimming competition yesterday afternoon
He prefers to backstroke because it's easier on his neck and shoulders

definitions: retrace one's steps or go back along the same path that was previously taken
reverse or change one's position opinion or statement to something said or believed earlier
examples: The hikers had to backtrack when they realized they were on the wrong trail
She backtracked through the forest to find the campsite she had missed
The politician backtracked on his earlier statement about tax increases during the debate
When presented with new evidence he backtracked on his original theory completely

definitions: mark identify or distinguish someone or something with a badge or similar symbol
pester or harass someone persistently with requests questions or demands
examples: Security badged all visitors with temporary identification cards at the entrance
The company badges employees with different colors to indicate their departments
The reporter badged the senator with questions about the corruption scandal
Children often badge their parents with requests for treats and toys

definitions: pester harass or bother someone persistently and repeatedly especially with questions or requests
examples: The journalists badgered the celebrity with questions about her personal life
He badgered his parents for weeks until they agreed to buy him a car

definitions: confuse or perplex someone completely so they cannot understand or explain something
examples: The complex mathematical equation baffled even the most experienced professors
Her strange behavior baffled everyone who knew her well before

definitions: put something into a bag or container for storage transport or disposal
capture obtain or secure something especially something difficult to get
abandon quit or give up on something especially a plan or activity
examples: She bagged the groceries carefully to prevent the eggs from breaking
Workers bagged the leaves that had fallen during the autumn season
The hunter bagged a deer during the first day of hunting season
She finally bagged the promotion she had been working toward for years
They decided to bag the camping trip when the weather forecast showed storms
Let's just bag this whole project since it's not working out well

definitions: provide money as security for someone's temporary release from jail before trial
remove water from a boat or container using a bucket or similar implement
help someone out of a difficult situation by providing assistance or support
abandon or leave something quickly especially when in trouble or difficulty
examples: His family bailed him out of jail after posting fifty thousand dollars bond
The lawyer arranged to bail the defendant pending trial next month
The crew bailed water frantically as the boat began taking on more
She bailed the rainwater from the leaky basement with large buckets
Her friends bailed her out when she couldn't afford rent this month
The government bailed out the failing bank to prevent economic collapse
He bailed on the date when he realized she wasn't interested
The investors bailed out of the stock market before prices crashed

definitions: lure or entice something especially fish or animals using food or other attractive substances
provoke harass or tease someone deliberately to make them angry or react
examples: The fisherman baited his hook with fresh worms before casting the line
They baited the trap with cheese to catch the mice in the basement
The bully baited the new student with cruel comments about his appearance
She refused to let her brother bait her into an argument again

definitions: cook food in an oven using dry heat without direct exposure to flame
become extremely hot especially from sun or high temperature
examples: She baked chocolate chip cookies for the school fundraiser this afternoon
The bread needs to bake for forty-five minutes at three fifty degrees
The desert travelers baked under the relentless sun for hours without shade
The pavement baked in the summer heat making it too hot to walk

definitions: keep something steady and stable without falling over by distributing weight evenly
make two or more things equal in weight amount force or importance
consider different factors carefully before making a decision or forming an opinion
examples: She balanced carefully on the narrow beam during her gymnastics routine
He balanced the heavy books on his head while walking across campus
The accountant balanced the company's books before the quarterly financial report
We need to balance the budget by reducing expenses or increasing revenue
The judge balanced the evidence before reaching a verdict in the case
She balanced her career ambitions with family responsibilities throughout her life

definitions: compress and bind hay straw or other material into large compact bundles for storage
remove water from a boat or container especially in emergency situations
examples: The farmers baled the hay after it dried completely in the summer sun
The machine baled the cotton into perfect rectangular bundles for shipping
The crew baled frantically as water poured through the damaged hull
They baled the flooded basement using buckets and pumps all night long

definitions: refuse to proceed or continue with something especially when stubborn or unwilling
hesitate or stop suddenly especially when faced with something difficult or unpleasant
examples: The horse balked at jumping over the high fence during training
She balked when asked to work overtime again this weekend
He balked at the idea of moving to another city for work
The committee balked at approving such a large budget increase this year

definitions: shape or form something into a round compact mass or sphere
play a game or engage in activity involving a ball
examples: She balled up the paper and threw it into the trash can
The dough balls easily when you work it with your hands
The children balled happily in the playground after school ended
They balled all afternoon playing various sports and games together

definitions: fill with air or gas to expand into a rounded shape
increase rapidly in size amount or intensity beyond normal or expected levels
examples: The children ballooned their colorful party balloons before the celebration began
Hot air ballooned the fabric making it rise gracefully into the sky
The debt ballooned from manageable to overwhelming in just two short years
Her popularity ballooned after the successful movie launch last month

definitions: vote in an election or decision by marking a ballot or casting votes officially
examples: Citizens balloted on the important constitutional amendment during the special election
Union members balloted to decide whether to accept the new contract terms

definitions: deceive confuse or trick someone through clever manipulation or misleading information
examples: The con artist bamboozled elderly people out of their life savings
Don't let the complicated contract language bamboozle you into signing something unfavorable

definitions: prohibit or forbid something officially especially by law regulation or authority
examples: The city banned smoking in all public buildings and restaurants
The school banned cell phones during class hours to improve focus

definitions: form or organize into a group especially for a common purpose or activity
encircle surround or bind something with a band strip or similar material
unite or come together with others for mutual support or common cause
examples: The musicians banded together to form a new jazz ensemble this summer
Local businesses banded to fight the proposed tax increase effectively
The veterinarian banded the bird's leg with an identification ring for tracking
Workers banded the packages securely with plastic straps before shipping
The neighbors banded together to organize the community clean-up day
Citizens banded to protest the unfair housing development in their area

definitions: apply a bandage or dressing to a wound injury or body part for protection and healing
examples: The nurse bandaged his injured knee carefully after cleaning the wound
She bandaged the cut on her finger to prevent infection from setting in

definitions: exchange words or remarks especially in an argumentative or heated manner
discuss or mention something casually or without serious consideration
examples: The lawyers bandied insults back and forth during the heated courtroom debate
They bandied harsh words during their argument about money yesterday
The committee bandied several ideas around before settling on the final plan
Politicians often bandy about promises they have no intention of keeping

definitions: strike or hit something hard making a loud sharp noise
close something forcefully and noisily especially a door or window
make a loud sudden noise by hitting or exploding
examples: He banged his fist on the table to get everyone's attention
She banged the hammer against the stubborn nail repeatedly
Don't bang the door when you leave the house please
The wind banged the shutters against the building all night long
The fireworks banged loudly in the sky during the celebration
Thunder banged overhead as the storm moved through the area

definitions: send someone away from a place permanently as punishment or because they are unwanted
dismiss or drive away thoughts feelings or memories from one's mind
examples: The king banished the traitor from the kingdom for life
The community banished the criminal after his repeated offenses against neighbors
She tried to banish all negative thoughts from her mind before the exam
Meditation helps banish stress and anxiety from daily life effectively

definitions: deposit money or valuables in a bank or financial institution for safekeeping
rely depend or count on someone or something with confidence
tilt or incline to one side especially when turning or changing direction
examples: She banks her paycheck every Friday afternoon without fail
Smart investors bank their profits during good market conditions regularly
You can bank on her arriving exactly on time for every meeting
We're banking on good weather for the outdoor wedding this weekend
The airplane banked sharply to the left to avoid the mountain range
The motorcycle banked into the curve at high speed during the race

definitions: cause someone or something to become financially ruined unable to pay debts or meet obligations
examples: The lawsuit bankrupted the small company within six months of filing
Medical bills bankrupted the family despite their insurance coverage unfortunately

definitions: hold or attend a formal elaborate meal or feast especially for celebration or ceremony
examples: The company banqueted its employees at the annual holiday celebration this year
They banqueted in honor of the retiring professor's forty years of service

definitions: exchange light-hearted playful or teasing remarks in a friendly conversational manner
examples: The colleagues bantered good-naturedly during their coffee break this morning
The old friends bantered like teenagers despite being in their sixties now

definitions: perform the Christian sacrament of baptism by immersing in or sprinkling with water
initiate someone formally into a group activity or situation for the first time
examples: The minister baptized the infant in the church ceremony last Sunday
She was baptized as an adult after finding faith later in life
The difficult project baptized the new employee into company culture quickly
His first day in combat baptized him into the realities of war

definitions: block prevent or obstruct someone or something from passing through or accessing
exclude someone formally from participating in something or entering somewhere
fasten secure or strengthen something with a bar or similar barrier
examples: The fallen tree barred the road forcing traffic to take alternate routes
Heavy security barred protesters from entering the government building today
The scandal barred him from holding public office for ten years
Poor grades barred her from participating in extracurricular activities this semester
Workers barred the windows before the hurricane arrived to protect the glass
She barred the door securely before going to bed last night

definitions: provide something with barbs sharp points or similar protective or aggressive features
make cutting critical or hurtful remarks designed to wound or provoke
examples: The workers barbed the fence with razor wire to prevent unauthorized entry
Nature barbed the rose stems to protect the delicate flowers from animals
She barbed him with sarcastic comments about his failed business venture
The critic barbed the actor's performance with unusually harsh reviews yesterday

definitions: cook meat vegetables or other food over an open fire or on a grill
hold an outdoor party or gathering featuring grilled food and social activities
examples: They barbecued ribs and corn for the family reunion this weekend
He loves to barbecue steaks on his new gas grill every summer
The neighbors barbecued in their backyard to celebrate the holiday together
We barbecued last Saturday with friends and played games until midnight

definitions: cook meat vegetables or other food over an open fire or on a grill
hold an outdoor party or gathering featuring grilled food and social activities
examples: They barbequed chicken and vegetables for the church picnic this afternoon
She loves to barbeque salmon on cedar planks during summer evenings
The community barbequed in the park for the annual fundraising event
They barbequed every weekend during the warm months with different neighbor families

definitions: cut trim or style someone's hair professionally especially men's hair in a barbershop
examples: The experienced barber barbered the gentleman's hair with precision and skill
He has barbered hair in this neighborhood for over thirty years now

definitions: uncover or expose something by removing what covers or conceals it
reveal or show something completely especially secrets thoughts or emotions
examples: The archaeologist bared the ancient artifacts after careful excavation work
Wind and rain bared the tree roots during the severe storm
The witness bared the truth about the corruption scandal during testimony
She bared her soul to her closest friend during their conversation

definitions: negotiate or discuss the price terms or conditions of something to reach agreement
expect anticipate or count on something happening especially something unpleasant
examples: She bargained with the vendor until they agreed on a fair price
Union representatives bargained for better working conditions and increased wages
He didn't bargain for such heavy traffic when planning his commute time
They bargained on good weather but got rain instead during their vacation

definitions: move somewhere in a forceful clumsy or aggressive manner without consideration
intrude or enter somewhere rudely without permission or invitation
examples: He barged through the crowded hallway knocking people aside carelessly
The bull barged through the fence into the neighboring field
She barged into the meeting without knocking or asking permission first
Don't barge into their conversation when they're having a private discussion
